meta.name: The Fetha Nagast (Law of the Kings)
meta.description: The comprehensive Ethiopic code covering both Ecclesiastical (Spiritual) and Civil (Secular) law.

chapters.name: On the Church and its Sanctity

verses.text: The Church is the house of God, a place of prayer and sanctification. It must be built with the permission of the Bishop and consecrated with the Holy Myron.
No worldly business, commerce, or clamor shall be conducted within its walls, for it is the gate of heaven upon earth.
The books that are to be read in the Church are the eighty-one books of the Old and New Testaments, as delivered by the Apostles.
These are the source of all law and truth, and no man shall add to them or diminish from them.
Baptism is the first gate to the kingdom. It shall be performed with water in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit.
Infants shall be baptized on the fortieth day if they are male, and on the eightieth day if they are female, unless there be danger of death.
The Patriarch is the father of all and the head of the spiritual host. He shall be chosen for his holiness, his knowledge of the law, and his blameless life.
He has the authority to ordain Bishops and to oversee the unity of the faith across the land.
The Bishop shall be a man of wisdom, not less than fifty years of age, unless a younger man be found of extraordinary grace.
He is the shepherd of his diocese and is responsible for the souls of the clergy and the laity alike.
The Priest shall be ordained after reaching the age of thirty. He must be a man of one wife or live in celibacy.
His duty is to offer the Holy Sacrifice, to teach the Word, and to hear the confessions of the faithful.
The Deacon is the servant of the altar. He shall be ordained at the age of twenty-five and must be found blameless in his conduct.
He assists the Priest in the liturgy and manages the charity of the Church toward the poor.
The Sub-Deacon assists the Deacon, and the Reader proclaims the scriptures. They are the lower pillars of the sanctuary.

chapters.name: On the Liturgy and the Eucharist

verses.text: The Holy Offering shall be made with pure wheaten bread and wine of the grape. It is the true Body and Blood of Christ.
No person under penance or possessed by a spirit shall draw near to the mysteries until they are cleansed.
The great fasts are the Fast of the Prophets, the Fast of Nineveh, the Great Lent, and the Fasts of Wednesday and Friday.
Fasting consists of abstaining from food until the appointed hour and from all animal products.
The faithful shall pray seven times a day, standing toward the East, as a sign of their expectation of the Lord's return.

chapters.name: On the Feast of the Resurrection

verses.text: Easter is the feast of feasts. Its calculation shall follow the canon of Nicaea, ensuring the whole Church celebrates as one.
Those who suffered for the faith shall be honored with feast days and their relics kept in reverence.
The monk dies to the world to live for God. He must keep the vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience under a spiritual father.
A tenth of all produce and gain belongs to the Lord for the maintenance of the sanctuary and the support of the needy.
No member of the clergy shall lend money at interest, for it is a sin that devours the poor.

chapters.name: On the Judgment of the Clergy

verses.text: A Priest or Deacon who commits a grave sin shall be deposed from his office, but he shall not be excommunicated from the laity unless he remains unrepentant.
Let the faithful abstain from the blood of animals and from things strangled, according to the apostolic decree.
Clothing should be modest and fitting for one's station, avoiding the vanity of the world which leads to pride.
Marriage is a covenant made before God. It requires the consent of the parents and the free will of the man and the woman.
The degrees of consanguinity must be observed; no man shall marry within the forbidden seven generations of his kindred.
A man may have only one wife, for the union of the flesh represents the union of Christ and the Church.
The gift given by the husband to the wife at the time of the wedding remains her property as a security for her future.
He who borrows must repay at the appointed time. If a man is unable to pay due to poverty, the creditor should show mercy as the Lord showed mercy to us.
A deposit is a sacred trust. If a man leaves his goods with another, the keeper is responsible for their safety as if they were his own.
He who acts on behalf of another must do so with honesty and diligence, seeking the benefit of his principal in all things.
A sale is completed when there is agreement on the price and the thing is delivered. Let there be no deceit or hidden defects in the transaction.
Partners shall share in both profit and loss according to the measure of their contribution, walking together in transparency.
The price for the use of land or animals shall be agreed upon beforehand, and the property shall be returned in the condition it was received.
A gift made while a man is in health is valid upon delivery; a gift made in the shadow of death is subject to the laws of inheritance.
A man has the right to dispose of his property before he dies, provided he provides for his children and his wife according to the law.
When a man dies without a will, his property shall descend first to his children, then to his parents, then to his brothers and sisters.
Male and female children shall inherit together, for they are equal in the sight of their father.
The orphan and the minor shall be protected by a guardian, who shall manage their affairs with the fear of God until they reach the age of maturity.
The King is appointed by God to maintain justice and to protect the Church. He must rule with mercy and follow the laws of the fathers.
The people owe the King obedience in all things that do not contradict the commandments of God.
He who kills a man intentionally shall be put to death by the sword of justice. He who kills by accident shall seek refuge and pay the blood-price.
The thief shall restore fourfold what he has taken. If he cannot pay, he shall labor until the debt is satisfied.

chapters.name: On the Final Judgment of the Law

verses.text: Let all these laws be kept with diligence, for he who keeps the law of the earth prepares himself for the law of heaven.
May the peace of the King of Kings be with all who walk in the path of justice. Amen.
